div.p: S. D. I have received all the letters you sent to me; I thank you for all of them.

I believe you have received those which I sent back through Anton Burkhard, our fellow citizen, as you requested. The incident with the broken barrel quite alarmed me; for I feared that it might have caused your mother-in-law greater harm than you had written; but I am glad she is now feeling better. I would have sent those letters, which I have now written about, sooner; but they did not seem to contain anything special. You will learn more fully what is happening with us, if you wish, from Mr. Herter, the courier.

Some Papists, a kind of people, as you know, hostile to us, have somewhat disturbed our pleasant gathering. As far as I can gather, those Baden baths, as they call them, do not entirely agree with my constitution; I can hardly tolerate the heat. I have nothing more to write now, except that, when the next synod is held, you excuse me for not appearing in person. I suppose you have heard about the diet held in Schwyz.

The people of Schwyz, who bathe with us, have revealed everything to us. There has never been greater dissension among them; it was celebrated with great and insane outcries from both parties; the same is predicted to happen among the people of Zug on the next Sunday. Mr. Hartmann von Hallwil has not yet come to us; we await his arrival daily.
I commend my family to you, which I am sure is commended to you even without my speaking. Please greet my mother-in-law, relatives, and my Margaret for me.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his dearest father.
